questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to the office for the evaluation of amenorrhea. The patient’s menarche was at the age of 13, and her menstrual cycle has been regular with menses occurring every 28 days. For the past 8 months, the patient has not menstruated. She is sexually active with her boyfriend and uses condoms consistently. The patient plays on the high school soccer team and frequently competes in local beauty pageants. She follows a calorie-restricted dietary regimen and exercises 3 hours every day. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min and blood pressure is 90/55 mmHg. BMI is 16 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Physical examination shows a pale, thin girl of normal stature with fine hair and Tanner stage III breast and pubic hair growth. Rest of the examination is within normal limits. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following set of hormonal changes will be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with functional hypothalamic amenorrhea (FHA), suggested by secondary amenorrhea, low body weight, the following of a low-calorie diet and intense exercise regimen, and examination finding of lanugo (fine hair indicating calorie restriction).

FHA can be seen in competitive athletes, dancers and models or others that maintain a very low calorie diet. It is characterized by decrease in hypothalamic gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) secretion, leading to decreased amplitude and/or frequency of gonadotropin pulses, absence of normal follicular development, absent midcycle surge in luteinizing hormone (LH) secretion, absent follicular stimulating hormone (FSH) secretion, anovulation, and low serum estradiol concentrations. Common associated conditions include anorexia nervosa and celiac disease (secondary to malabsorption).

Such patients are at increased risk of consequences of estrogen deficiency, including low bone density, infertility, breast and/or vaginal atrophy, and sexual dysfunction.  

Option Analysis

❌   GnRH  FSH LH  Estradiol  Prolactin  Normal  Increased  Increased  Decreased  Normal :
Incorrect: These findings are suggestive of amenorrhea seen in Turner syndrome. The patients have low estrogen levels leading to amenorrhea and absent breast development. The FSH and LH levels are elevated due to lack of negative feedback from estrogen. This patient had a normal menstrual cycle previously and has well-developed secondary sexual characteristics.
✅   GnRH  FSH  LH  Estradiol  Prolactin  Decreased  Decreased or normal Decreased Decreased  Normal :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  GnRH  FSH  LH Estradiol  Prolactin  Normal DecreasedDecreased Decreased Increased:
Incorrect: An elevated prolactin with decreased levels of FSH, LH and estradiol are suggestive of prolactinoma. Patients usually present with bilateral breast discharge, visual changes and frequent headaches, in combination with amenorrhea.
❌  GnRH FSH  LH  Estradiol  Prolactin  Normal  Normal/decreasedNormal/ElevatedNormal Normal :
Incorrect: The LH/FSH ratio of ≥2 is usually seen in polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), a disorder that is characterized by failure of follicle maturation and oocyte release. Patients usually present with obesity, amenorrhea, infertility and/or signs of hyperandrogenism (e.g., acne and hirsutism).
❌  GnRH FSH LH Estradiol Prolactin Decreased Undetectable UndetectableUndetectable Normal :
Incorrect: Patients with congenital GnRH deficiency (Kallman syndrome) can present with very low or undetectable levels of GnRH, FSH and LH. It is unlikely in this patient, as she had a normal menstrual cycle previously.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man visits the physician for a follow-up. The patient was diagnosed with idiopathic primary hypogonadism one year ago after experiencing erectile dysfunction and decreased energy. He was then started on androgen replacement using intramuscular testosterone cypionate. Currently, he is feeling better, with improvement in his energy levels and sexual function. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is expected to be seen in this patient due to his treatment?
questions.solution:
This patient is being treated for hypogonadism using testosterone cypionate, a testosterone derivative used in androgen replacement therapy. It can cause an elevation in hematocrit as a side effect.

Testosterone derivatives are a group of androgenic hormones that have the structure of testosterone. Testosterone cypionate is one of these derivatives used intramuscularly, while fluoxymesterone and methyltestosterone are oral ones. Testosterone derivatives are usually used in androgen replacement therapy in patients with primary or secondary hypogonadism. It can also stimulate anabolism in patients with severe catabolic states (e.g. burn patients).

Side effects of testosterone derivatives are common. First, these drugs stimulate erythropoiesis, leading to increased erythrocyte production and hematocrit. Furthermore, they can increase the growth of the prostate gland as testosterone will be converted to dihydrotestosterone, which directly stimulates the growth of the prostate gland. Because of this effect, prostate-specific antigen (PSA) can increase in patients taking testosterone derivatives, and sometimes there is a slightly increased risk of prostate cancer. Other side effects include increased LDL and decreased HDL, gynecomastia, gonadal atrophy, and infertility.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Elevated hematocrit:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Elevated follicle stimulating hormone:
Incorrect: This patient is expected to have a decreased follicle stimulating hormone after starting testosterone treatment because it causes feedback inhibition of the gonadotrophs in the pituitary gland, leading to suppression of FSH release.  
❌ Elevated high-density lipoprotein (HDL):
Incorrect: Patients taking testosterone are expected to have an increased LDL and decreased HDL.  
❌ Decreased prostate gland size:
Incorrect: Testosterone is converted to dihydrotestosterone (DHT) by 5-alpha reductase enzyme. DHT then stimulates the growth of the prostate gland. Therefore, patients on testosterone replacement therapy usually have an increase in the size of the prostate gland.  
❌ Galactorrhea:
Incorrect:  Although testosterone hormone supplementation can lead to gynecomastia due to peripheral aromatization to estrogens, it is not associated with galactorrhea.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is diagnosed with age-related progressive bilateral sensorineural hearing loss of higher frequencies. Which of the following components of the auditory system detects high frequency vibrations?
questions.solution:
Presbycusis is age related progressive sensorineural hearing loss, often of higher frequencies, due to the destruction of hair cells at the cochlear base.

Normally, vibrations lead to stimulation of a specific location on the cochlea’s basilar membrane depending on the sound frequency. High-frequency sounds stimulate hair cells at the base of the cochlea, which has a thin and rigid basilar membrane. In contrast, low-frequency sounds stimulate hair cells at the apex of the cochlea near an area called the helicotrema, which has a wide and flexible basilar membrane.  

Option Analysis

❌ Apex of cochlea  :
Incorrect: Low-frequency sounds stimulate hair cells in the cochlear apex near an area called the helicotrema.  
✅ Base of cochlea  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Auditory canal  :
Incorrect: The auditory canal and tympanic membrane transfer sound waves to the inner ear. In the inner ear, the cochlea then converts the sound waves into nerve signals.  
❌ Middle ear ossicles  :
Incorrect: The ossicles conduct sound waves as they travel from the tympanic membrane to the inner ear. However, in age-related hearing loss, the underlying pathophysiology is damage to hair cells within the cochlea.  
❌ Tympanic membrane  :
Incorrect: The tympanic membrane transfers sound from the external ear to the middle ear. However, in age-related hearing loss, the underlying pathophysiology is damage to hair cells within the cochlea.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man is diagnosed with Bell palsy and has paralysis of the stapedius muscle. Which of the following is true regarding the stapedius muscle in the middle ear?

choices.text: It arises from the cartilaginous part of the auditory tube and the adjoining part of the sphenoid.
It detects low frequency sound vibrations.
Contraction of the muscle pulls the malleus medially.
It controls the amplitude of sound waves being transmitted to the inner ear.
It allows pressure to be equalized on both sides of the tympanic membrane.

questions.solution:
Contraction of stapedius muscle pulls the neck of the stapes laterally, thereby dampening the vibrations of the stapes and controlling the amplitude of sound waves being transmitted to the inner ear.

The ear is anatomically divided into 3 parts:

1) External ear: The external ear is composed of the auricle, which collects sound, and the external acoustic meatus (ear canal), which conducts sound to the tympanic membrane. The tympanic membrane forms a partition between the external acoustic meatus and the tympanic cavity of the middle ear.

2) Middle ear: The middle ear is a chamber in the petrous part of the temporal bone. It is connected anteromedially with the nasopharynx by the pharyngotympanic (eustachian) tube. It is connected posterosuperiorly with the mastoid cells through the mastoid antrum. The contents of the middle ear include:

  •  Auditory ossicles (malleus, incus, and stapes): The ossicles receive acoustic vibrations from the tympanic membrane and amplify them. They then transmit the amplified acoustic vibrations to the fluid of the inner ear via the oval window. 
  •  Eustachian tube: The pharyngotympanic (eustachian) tube controls the pressure within the middle ear and allows the pressure to be equalized on both sides of the tympanic membrane. 
  •  Stapedius and tensor tympani muscles: These muscles dampen transmission of loud noises to the inner ear. 
  •  Chorda tympani nerve: This nerve is a branch of CN VII. 
  •  Tympanic plexus of nerves 
3) Inner ear: The inner ear contains organs of hearing (e.g. cochlea) and equilibrium (e.g. vestibule).  

Option Analysis

❌ It arises from the cartilaginous part of the auditory tube and the adjoining part of the sphenoid.  :
Incorrect: The tensor tympani muscle arises from the cartilaginous part of the auditory tube and the adjoining part of the sphenoid.  
❌ It detects low frequency sound vibrations.  :
Incorrect: Low frequency sounds are detected and converted into nerve signals at the cochlear apex in the inner ear.  
❌ Contraction of the muscle pulls the malleus medially.  :
Incorrect: Contraction of the tensor tympani muscle pulls the malleus medially, whereas contraction of stapedius pulls the neck of the stapes laterally.  
✅ It controls the amplitude of sound waves being transmitted to the inner ear.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ It allows pressure to be equalized on both sides of the tympanic membrane.  :
Incorrect: The eustachian tube controls pressure within the middle ear and allows pressure to be equalized on both sides of the tympanic membrane. This functionality is important for altitude compensation, such as when someone is traveling on an airplane.

questions.text:
A fundoscopic examination is performed on a healthy individual as part of a routine physical examination. The following is visualized:


Source: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is true regarding the area marked with the arrow?

choices.text: It contains both rods and cones.
It is where the optic nerve leaves.

questions.solution:
The retina is the innermost layer of the eye which contains photoreceptors and is responsible for processing light into brain signals. When examined with a fundoscope, many of the retinal structures can be identified.    

First, in the center of the retina is the optic disc. The central disc is the exit site for the central retinal vein and optic nerve, as well as the entry site of the central retinal artery (a branch of the ophthalmic artery). The optic disc contains no photoreceptors and therefore forms a blind spot in the visual field.    

Lateral to the optic disc is the macula. The macula is the most sensitive area in the retina and contains only cones. It is responsible for high-acuity vision. In the center of the macula is an area called the fovea centralis. The fovea is more depressed than the rest of the rest of the macula, and it is the place where the highest-acuity vision is sensed.



Option Analysis

❌ It contains no photoreceptors.:
Incorrect: The macula is the most sensitive part of the retina and contains only cones.
❌ It contains both rods and cones.:
Incorrect: The macula of the retina is responsible for the acuity of vision and contains only cones.
❌ It contains only rods.:
Incorrect: The macula contains no rods and only cones.
❌ It is where the optic nerve leaves.:
Incorrect: The optic nerve leaves at the optic disc, which is medial to the macula.
✅ It contains only cones.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the office for evaluation of a painful tongue sore. The sore is on the median sulcus of the tongue, located 2 cm anterior to the foramen cecum. Taste sensation in this region of the tongue is carried by which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
Innervation of the tongue is complex, as there are motor, general sensory, and gustatory (taste) components.

Motor innervation is provided by: 
  •  Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII): hyoglossus, genioglossus, and styloglossus muscles 
  •  Vagus nerve (CN X): palatoglossus muscle 
General sensory innervation including touch, pain, pressure, and temperature is provided by: 
  •  Anterior two-thirds of the tongue: mandibular branch of trigeminal nerve (CN V3) 
  •  Posterior one-third of the tongue: glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) 
  •  Posterior area of the tongue: vagus nerve (CN X) 
Gustatory innervation (taste buds) are as follows: 
  •  Anterior two-thirds of the tongue: chorda tympani branch of facial nerve (CN VII) 
  •  Posterior one-third of the tongue: glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) 
  •  Posterior area of the tongue root and taste buds of the larynx and upper esophagus: vagus nerve (CN X) 


Option Analysis

❌ Vagus nerve  :
Incorrect: The vagus nerve (CN X) innervates the far posterior area of the tongue root, transmitting both gustatory and general sensory stimuli.  
✅ Chorda tympani  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Glossopharyngeal nerve  :
Incorrect: The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) transmits taste, pain, temperature, and touch stimuli from the posterior one-third of the tongue.  
❌ Mandibular branch of trigeminal nerve  :
Incorrect: The mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3) transmits pain, temperature, and touch from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.  
❌ Hypoglossal nerve  :
Incorrect: The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) provides motor innervation to the tongue.

questions.text: An experiment is performed to determine the reactions of the eye to different environments. In the first part of the experiment, an individual is kept in a dark room for 2 hours. After 2 hours, the light in the room is turned on. Which of the following best describes the changes expected to be seen in this individual?

choices.text: Increased parasympathetic stimulation of the sphincter pupillae muscle, causing miosis
Increased sympathetic stimulation of the sphincter pupillae muscle, causing miosis
Increased parasympathetic stimulation of the dilator pupillae muscle, causing mydriasis
Increased sympathetic stimulation of the dilator pupillae muscle, causing mydriasis
Increased parasympathetic stimulation of the ciliary muscles, causing miosis

questions.solution:
In order for light to reach the retina, it has to pass through different structures including the cornea, aqueous humor, pupil, lens, and vitreous humor. The lens shape and pupil size can be modified to allow for better vision in different environments.   The pupil is an opening in the iris just in front of the lens. The pupil size changes to control the amount of light reaching the retina. This process is controlled by two muscles within the iris, the sphincter pupillae and dilator pupillae, which are controlled by the autonomic nervous system.



When transitioning from a darker to a brighter environment, the parasympathetic nervous system stimulates the sphincter pupillae muscle. This causes muscle contraction and decreased pupillary diameter to prevent excess light from reaching the retina. The result is called miosis.



In contrast, when transitioning from a brighter to a darker environment, the sympathetic nervous system stimulates the dilator pupillae muscle. This dilates the pupil, allowing more light to reach the retina. The result is called mydriasis.



The ciliary body is made of blood vessels and smooth muscles. The ciliary processes attach to the lens by the suspensory ligaments of the lens. The ciliary body controls the lens’s curvature via contraction and relaxation of the smooth muscles within the ciliary body.

When focusing on distant objects, sympathetic innervation causes the ciliary muscles to relax. This results in stretching of the lens’s suspensory ligaments, thereby thinning the lens and enabling the eye to focus on distant objects.

Option Analysis

✅ Increased parasympathetic stimulation of the sphincter pupillae muscle, causing miosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increased sympathetic stimulation of the sphincter pupillae muscle, causing miosis:
Incorrect: The sympathetic nervous system is responsible for dilation of the pupil by stimulating the dilator pupillae muscle. In contrast, the parasympathetic nervous system is responsible for constriction of the pupil by stimulating the sphincter pupillae muscle.
❌ Increased parasympathetic stimulation of the dilator pupillae muscle, causing mydriasis:
Incorrect: The sympathetic nervous system is responsible for dilation of the pupil (mydriasis) by stimulating the dilator pupillae muscle. However, when transitioning from a darker to brighter environment, the parasympathetic nervous system instead stimulates the sphincter pupillae muscle to constrict the pupil and prevent excessive light from reaching the retina.
❌ Increased sympathetic stimulation of the dilator pupillae muscle, causing mydriasis:
Incorrect: When transitioning from a brighter to darker environment, the sympathetic nervous system stimulates the dilator pupillae muscle to cause mydriasis. However, when transitioning from a darker to brighter environment, the parasympathetic nervous system stimulates the sphincter pupillae muscle to instead constrict the pupil and prevent excessive light from reaching the retina.
❌ Increased parasympathetic stimulation of the ciliary muscles, causing miosis:
Incorrect: Parasympathetic stimulation of the ciliary muscle does not control pupil size, but alters the shape of the lens.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents with drooping of the right eyelid and diplopia. Physical examination shows the right eye is pointing downwards and outwards. Which of the following nerves is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The movement of each eyeball is controlled by the six extraocular muscles innervated by CN III, IV, and VI. The muscles arise from a common tendinous ring in the posterior part of the orbit. The exception is the inferior oblique muscle, which originates anteriorly on the floor of the orbit and runs posterolaterally to insert in the lateral part of the sclera. The function of each extraocular muscle is as follows:  

  •  Superior rectus muscle (CN III): Elevation of the eye, with adduction and intorsion 
  • Inferior rectus muscle (CN III): Depression of the eye, with adduction and extorsion 
  •  Lateral rectus muscle (CN VI): Abduction of the eye 
  •  Medial rectus muscle (CN III): Adduction of the eye 
  •  Superior oblique muscle (CN IV): This muscle courses along the medial wall of the orbit, traverses a fibrous sling (trochlea), courses backward, and inserts on the superolateral region of the eyeball. It moves the eyeball downwards and outwards (depression and abduction) with intorsion. 
  • Inferior oblique muscle (CN III): This muscle originates on the medial wall of the bony orbit and courses laterally and obliquely to insert on the inferolateral surface of the eyeball. It moves the eyeball upwards and outwards (elevation and abduction) with extorsion. 

Option Analysis

❌ Optic nerve  :
Incorrect: Damage to the optic nerve typically causes permanent and potentially severe loss of vision, as well as an abnormal pupillary reflex. It does not innervate the extraocular muscles.  
✅ Oculomotor nerve  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Trochlear nerve  :
Incorrect: CN IV provides somatic motor innervation to the superior oblique muscle, which moves the eyeball downwards and outwards (depression and abduction), with intorsion. Its paralysis would lead to weakness of downward eye movement with consequent vertical diplopia. The affected eye would drift upwards relative to the normal eye, due to the unopposed actions of the remaining extraocular muscles. Furthermore, drooping of the eyelid is not seen with CN IV injury.  
❌ Abducens nerve  :
Incorrect: The abducens nerve provides somatic motor innervation to the lateral rectus muscle. Its paralysis will cause double vision (diplopia), due to the unopposed muscle tone of the medial rectus muscle. The affected eye would deviate medially.  
❌ Facial nerve  :
Incorrect: In the orbit, the functions of the facial nerve can be remembered with the mnemonic it “makes you cry” (parasympathetic innervation of the lacrimal gland) and “closes your eye” (branchial motor innervation of the orbicularis oculi muscle). Its paralysis would lead to an inability to close the eye and decreased lacrimation, thereby leading to corneal ulceration. Drooping of the eyelid would be atypical.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the physiology of vision. She identifies a cell responsible for processing light stimuli in bright environments and facilitating high-acuity vision. Which of the following cells was most likely identified?
questions.solution:
Photoreception is the process that describes how photoreceptors (e.g., rods, and cones) absorb light waves that enter the eye and convert them into electrical signals. These signals are then sent to the brain for visual processing.  

Rods are located in the periphery of the retina. They have a high concentration of rhodopsin, which makes rods sensitive to light. As a result, they allow for vision in dark conditions. In contrast, cones are located in the fovea, have a low sensitivity to light, and work best in bright conditions.   

Both rods and cones synapse with bipolar cells, which then synapse with the ganglion cells. Multiple rods can synapse with a single ganglion cell. In contrast, each cone synapses with its own distinct ganglion cells. As a result, cones provide high-acuity vision whereas rods provide low-acuity vision.   

Finally, the axons of the ganglion cells form the optic nerve and relay signals to the brain for processing and interpretation.   

Option Analysis

✅ Cone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Rod:
Incorrect: Rods are photoreceptors responsible for low-acuity vision in dimly lit environments. In contrast, cones are the cell type responsible for high-acuity vision in bright environments.  
❌ Ganglion cell  :
Incorrect: Retinal ganglion cells are bridging neurons that connect photoreceptors, such as rods and cones, to the central nervous system. They are not directly responsible for processing light stimuli that reach the retina.  
❌ Bipolar cell  :
Incorrect: Bipolar cells are interneurons that connect photoreceptors (e.g., rods, cones) with the retinal ganglion cells. Bipolar cells are not directly responsible for processing light stimuli that reach the retina.  
❌ Vestibular hair cell  :
Incorrect: Vestibular hair cells are located in the inner ear and can detect changes in motor and position. They are not responsible for facilitating vision.

questions.text: The auditory sensory organs are located within the membranous labyrinth. Which of the following is most appropriate regarding auditory signal transduction?

choices.text: The outer hair cells are responsible for the transduction of sound
The scala vestibuli and scala tympani are both filled with endolymph
Vibration of the round window causes a traveling wave in the basilar membrane
Low frequencies are heard at the apex near the helicotrema
Endolymph has a similar composition to other extracellular fluids

questions.solution:
The ear contains the organ of Corti which is responsible for transforming sound waves into electrical impulses. This organ is mechanically coupled to the external environment by the tympanic membrane and the middle ear ossicles (malleus, incus, and stapes). Pressure changes in the external auditory meatus, resulting from sound waves, cause the tympanic membrane to vibrate. These vibrations are transferred to the oval window. The middle ear amplifies the force of sound waves because the oval window has a smaller surface area than that of the tympanic membrane. When the vibration of the oval window causes a traveling wave in the basilar membrane, hair cells are pushed against the tectorial membrane. Each frequency leads to vibrations at specific locations on the basilar membrane–that is, low frequencies are heard at the apex near the helicotrema (wide and flexible) and high frequencies are heard best at the base of the cochlea (thin and rigid).  


Hair cells have a tall kinocilium at one edge of the cell, which is surrounded by approximately 100 stereocilia. Deformation of the stereocilia toward the large kinocilium results in the opening of mechanically gated cation channels. The resulting entry of potassium (K+) from the K+-rich endolymph causes depolarization of the hair cell and Ca2+ entry. The release of neurotransmitters by exocytosis from the base of the cell excites the neurites of the auditory neurons. Axons of the auditory nerve synapse first in the cochlear nuclei of the medulla. Many second-order neurons pass via the lateral lemniscus directly to the inferior colliculi, whereas others synapse in the superior olivary nucleus of the pons first. Third- (or fourth-) order neurons pass from the inferior colliculus to the medial geniculate nucleus of the thalamus, where the signal is relayed via the white matter of the acoustic radiation to the auditory cortex in the temporal lobe.  

Option Analysis

❌ The outer hair cells are responsible for the transduction of sound  :
Incorrect: The inner hair cells are responsible for the transduction of sound.  
❌ The scala vestibuli and scala tympani are both filled with endolymph  :
Incorrect: The scala vestibuli and scala tympani are both filled with perilymph, which has a similar composition to other extracellular fluids. Endolymph is the fluid contained in the membranous labyrinth of the inner ear.  
❌ Vibration of the round window causes a traveling wave in the basilar membrane  :
Incorrect: Vibration of the oval window causes a traveling wave in the basilar membrane.  
✅ Low frequencies are heard at the apex near the helicotrema  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Endolymph has a similar composition to other extracellular fluids  :
Incorrect: The scala media is a blind-ended structure that contains endolymph, an unusual extracellular fluid, because it has a high [K+] of 150 mM and a low [Na+] of 1 mM. In contrast, the scala vestibuli and scala tympani are both filled with perilymph which has a similar composition to other extracellular fluids.
